articles.headline: Joplin Defies Odds, Just by Opening Schools
articles.snippet: Joplin, Mo., has raced to regain its footing since a tornado killed 160 people and displaced thousands more three months ago.
articles.abstract: Joplin, Mo., has raced to regain its footing since a tornado killed 160 people and displaced thousands more three months ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOPLIN, Mo. — When the schools here were reduced to red-brick rubble in the deadly tornado three months ago, abruptly ending classes just before final exams, district leaders made a promise that seemed like a long shot: the new school year would start on time.

articles.headline: Abercrombie Wants Off ‘Jersey Shore’ (Wink-Wink)
articles.snippet: If Abercrombie & Fitch is really concerned that the Situation and company have appeared on air in its garments, it doesn’t appear that angry.
articles.abstract: If Abercrombie & Fitch is really concerned that the Situation and company have appeared on air in its garments, it doesn’t appear that angry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brands have pursued product placement for years, cutting deals to get sodas and sports cars in movies and on television. Some have even insisted on the opposite, having their logos and labels blurred by the camera when associated with the bad guy, for instance.

articles.headline: Bashing E.P.A. Is New Theme in G.O.P. Race
articles.snippet: Republican presidential hopefuls are portraying the Environmental Protection Agency as a symbol of a heavy-handed regulatory agenda that they say is strangling the economy.
articles.abstract: Republican presidential hopefuls are portraying the Environmental Protection Agency as a symbol of a heavy-handed regulatory agenda that they say is strangling the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency is emerging as a favorite target of the Republican presidential candidates, who portray it as the very symbol of a heavy-handed regulatory agenda imposed by the Obama administration that they say is strangling the economy.

articles.headline: Islamist Group With Possible Qaeda Links Upends Nigeria
articles.snippet: A shadowy Islamist insurgency that has haunted northern Nigeria appears to be branching out and collaborating with Al Qaeda’s affiliates.
articles.abstract: A shadowy Islamist insurgency that has haunted northern Nigeria appears to be branching out and collaborating with Al Qaeda’s affiliates.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — A shadowy Islamist insurgency that has haunted northern Nigeria — surviving repeated, bloody efforts to eliminate it — appears to be branching out and collaborating with Al Qaeda’s affiliates, alarming Western officials and analysts who had previously viewed the militants here as a largely isolated, if deadly, menace.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Files Were Illegally Destroyed, Lawyer Says
articles.snippet: A lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission said that thousands of documents involving inquiries into Bernard L. Madoff and other matters were destroyed.
articles.abstract: A lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission said that thousands of documents involving inquiries into Bernard L. Madoff and other matters were destroyed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An enforcement lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission says that the agency illegally destroyed files and documents related to thousands of early-stage investigations over the last 20 years, according to information released Wednesday by Congressional investigators.

articles.headline: Cuts in Health Care May Undermine Role in Labor Market
articles.snippet: Government spending cuts will be working their way through health services, but some believe this is no more than a lull in a sector that has been a jobs engine.
articles.abstract: Government spending cuts will be working their way through health services, but some believe this is no more than a lull in a sector that has been a jobs engine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even during months of stubborn unemployment, the health care industry has provided a solid underpinning, reliably adding jobs in an otherwise dismal environment.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: U.S. Inquiry Is Said to Focus on S.&P. Ratings
articles.snippet: The Justice Department is investigating whether Standard & Poor’s rated mortgage securities improperly leading up to the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department is investigating whether Standard & Poor’s rated mortgage securities improperly leading up to the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is investigating whether the nation’s largest credit ratings agency, Standard & Poor’s, improperly rated dozens of mortgage securities in the years leading up to the financial crisis, according to two people interviewed by the government and another briefed on such interviews.

articles.headline: Stocks Fall Anew on Debt Worries and the Economy
articles.snippet: The S.&P. dropped 4.5 percent amid heightened concerns over the impact of the euro zone debt crisis; Asia-Pacific markets fell sharply in early trading on Friday.
articles.abstract: The S.&P. dropped 4.5 percent amid heightened concerns over the impact of the euro zone debt crisis; Asia-Pacific markets fell sharply in early trading on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: After just a few days of calm, stock markets heaved again on Thursday, sending major American indexes down as much as 5 percent on persistent worries about the economy and Europe’s debt problems.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Christine Hauser

articles.headline: U.S. and Allies Say Syria Leader Must Step Down
articles.snippet: The call for Bashar al-Assad to give up power came after months of popular protests and deadly reprisals by Syrian authorities.
articles.abstract: The call for Bashar al-Assad to give up power came after months of popular protests and deadly reprisals by Syrian authorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and several of its major allies on Thursday called on Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, to give up power. The carefully choreographed announcements came after months of popular protests and increasingly deadly reprisals that the United Nations commissioner for human rights said amounted to crimes against humanity by the Syrian authorities.
